factoid: The accountant said, "Oh, leave off!"
The accountant had a beaming but rather cunning smile.
The accountant was flattered at being made the subject of Zherkóv’s joke.
The accountant was trying to appear stupider than he really was.
The accountant said, "What's that that has fallen?"
The accountant asked, "So that's what they hit with? How awful!"
Zherkóv answered, "A French pancake."
Zherkóv seemed to swell with satisfaction.
Zherkóv had hardly finished speaking when they again heard an unexpectedly violent whistling which suddenly ended with a thud into something soft.
A Cossack crashed to earth with his horse.
Zherkóv bent over his saddle and turned his horse away.
The staff officer bent over his saddle and turned his horse away.
The accountant stopped, faced the Cossack, and examined the Cossack with attentive curiosity.
The Cossack was dead.
The Cossack's horse was still struggling.
Prince Bagratión screwed up his eyes.
Prince Bagratión looked round.
Prince Bagratión saw the cause of the confusion.
Prince Bagratión turned away with indifference.
Prince Bagratión reined in his horse with the care of a skillful rider.
Prince Bagratión slightly bent over.
Prince Bagratión disengaged his saber which had caught in his cloak.
Prince Bagratión's saber was an old-fashioned saber of a kind no longer in general use.
Prince Andrew remembered the story of Suvórov giving his saber to Bagratión in Italy.
Prince Andrew found the recollection particularly pleasant at that moment.
Prince Andrew had been at the battery when he examined the battlefield.
They were all approaching Túshin's battery.
A ball struck the ground in front of them.
Prince Bagratión asked the artilleryman, "Whose company?".
Prince Bagratión really meant "Are you frightened here?" when he asked "Whose company?".
The red-haired, freckled gunner shouted, "Captain Túshin’s, your excellency!".
Prince Bagratión muttered, "Yes, yes.".
A ringing shot issued from the cannon, deafening Prince Bagratión and his suite.
In the smoke that surrounded the cannon, they could see the gunners straining to roll it quickly back to its former position.
Number One was a huge, broad-shouldered gunner holding a mop with his legs far apart and sprang to the wheel.
Number Two was a gunner with a trembling hand who placed a charge in the cannon’s mouth.
Captain Túshin was short and round-shouldered.
Captain Túshin stumbled over the tail of the gun carriage.
Captain Túshin moved forward.
Captain Túshin did not notice the general.
Captain Túshin looked out shading his eyes with his small hand.
Captain Túshin cried, "Lift it two lines more and it will be just right."
Captain Túshin cried in a feeble voice.
Captain Túshin tried to impart a dashing note to his voice.
Captain Túshin squeaked, "Number Two!".
Captain Túshin shouted, "Fire, Medvédev!".
Prince Bagratión called to Captain Túshin.
Captain Túshin raised three fingers to his cap with a bashful and awkward gesture.
Captain Túshin's gesture was not like a military salute but like a priest’s benediction.
Captain Túshin approached the general.
Captain Túshin's guns had been intended to cannonade the valley.
Captain Túshin was firing incendiary balls at the village of Schön Grabern.
The village of Schön Grabern was visible just opposite.
Large masses of French were advancing in front of the village of Schön Grabern.
